title: Univers CE/LT?
content: Hey, I wanted to know, what's the difference between Univers CE and Univers LT?
author: asshole

comments.content:
Univers CE fonts are available in PostScript Type 1 or TrueType formats, and they have the "Central European" character set.  
 [http://www.linotype.com/137563/universcentraleuropean55roman-font.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20130707113320/http:/www.linotype.com/137563/universcentraleuropean55roman-font.html "http://www.linotype.com/137563/universcentraleuropean55roman-font.html")  
 [http://www.linotype.com/137566/universcentraleuropean55roman-characterma...](http://web.archive.org/web/20130707113320/http:/www.linotype.com/137566/universcentraleuropean55roman-charactermap.html "http://www.linotype.com/137566/universcentraleuropean55roman-charactermap.html")

Univers LT is the Western European character set (with a Euro symbol). If you license the OpenType Com fonts (see [http://www.linotype.com/12641/univers55roman-font.html#format](http://web.archive.org/web/20130707113320/http:/www.linotype.com/12641/univers55roman-font.html#format "http://www.linotype.com/12641/univers55roman-font.html#format")), or the Pro fonts, you get both the Central European and the Western European glyph coverage! But if you need a non-OpenType font, you have to pick one or the other :(

My guess is that most people use OpenType now anyway. But I could be wrong!
For simple english, which should I use? because they're a bit different in some letters.
so what's up with your name ?

Thanks alot for your comments, Dan.  
Uhh my name? what about it?
